stem: Complete the monitoring protocol for a client receiving Magnesium Sulfate for preeclampsia.
template: A client on Magnesium Sulfate who develops {{symptom}} should be assessed immediately for toxicity. The nurse must have {{antidote}} available at the bedside at all times.

rationale.correct: Magnesium sulfate is a central nervous system (CNS) depressant administered to prevent seizures in clients with preeclampsia. It works by decreasing neuromuscular excitability.  A key sign of magnesium toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), indicating excessive CNS depression. Other signs include respiratory depression (RR < 12) and decreased level of consciousness. Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity; it counteracts the effects of magnesium by restoring normal neuromuscular function.  The nurse must have it readily available to administer if toxicity occurs.  Failure to recognize and treat magnesium toxicity can lead to respiratory arrest and cardiac arrest.
rationale.incorrect: Hyperactive reflexes are a characteristic of preeclampsia and indicate an increased risk for seizures, the very reason magnesium sulfate is being administered. Increased urine output is generally a positive sign, indicating adequate renal perfusion and magnesium excretion.

clinicalPearls: Closely monitor urine output (at least 30 mL/hr) because magnesium is primarily excreted by the kidneys. Decreased urine output can lead to magnesium accumulation and toxicity.  Assess respiratory rate frequently (every 1-2 hours) and be prepared to support ventilation if respiratory depression occurs.  Have oxygen and resuscitation equipment readily available.
Maintain a therapeutic magnesium level (4-7 mEq/L). Levels above 7 mEq/L increase the risk of toxicity.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that the primary goal of magnesium sulfate in preeclampsia is to PREVENT seizures (eclampsia), not to directly lower blood pressure, although it may have a mild antihypertensive effect.  For severe hypertension, medications like labetalol or hydralazine are typically used.

sbar.situation: Client receiving magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia.
sbar.background: Magnesium sulfate is administered to prevent seizures in preeclamptic clients. Therapeutic range is 4-7 mEq/L. Monitor for signs of toxicity.
sbar.assessment: Client exhibiting loss of deep tendon reflexes at 1400. Respiratory rate is 14 breaths/min. Urine output 25 mL/hr for the past two hours. Level of consciousness is slightly decreased.
sbar.recommendation: Suspect magnesium toxicity. Immediately discontinue magnesium infusion. Prepare to administer calcium gluconate per protocol. Anticipate possible respiratory support. Notify the provider immediately.

mnemonic.title: M-A-G
mnemonic.expansion: Muscle-relaxant, Antidote (Calcium Gluconate), Gracious-reflexes (Loss of DTRs).

reviewUnits.heading: High-Risk Pregnancy: Preeclampsia/Eclampsia
reviewUnits.body: Nurses perform hourly assessments: BP, RR (>12), DTRs, and Urine Output. Magnesium levels are checked if toxicity is suspected. Calcium Gluconate must be readily available.  Report any signs of toxicity immediately to the provider.  Document all assessments and interventions thoroughly.
